answer_html: All answers in the last line are equivalently correct.
answer_latex:
All answers in the last line are equivalently
correct.
hints_html:
Using the Pythagorean Theorem, we see that

\(\displaystyle D(t)^{2} = x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}\)

Differentiate this function.
hints_latex:
Using the Pythagorean Theorem, we see that

$\displaystyle D(t)^{2} = x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}$

Differentiate this function.
hints_raw:
Using the Pythagorean Theorem, we see that

<math> \displaystyle D(t)^{2} = x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}</math>

Differentiate this function.
question: 7 (ii)
sols_html:
As discussed in the hint,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle D(t)^{2} = x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}\end{aligned}\]

Differentiating yields

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2D(t)\frac{dD}{dt} = 2x\frac{dx}{dt} + 2y\frac{dy}{dt}\end{aligned}\]

From the previous part, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 2\end{aligned}\]

and we are given that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 8\end{aligned}\]

and so plugging in the point \(\displaystyle (x(t),y(t)) = (2,4)\), and \(\displaystyle D(t) = \sqrt{x(t)^2+y(t)^2}\) (D must be positive) we have

\[\begin{aligned} 2\sqrt{x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}}\frac{dD}{dt} &= 2D(t)\frac{dD}{dt} = 2x(t)\frac{dx}{dt} + 2y(t)\frac{dy}{dt} \\ 2\sqrt{(2)^{2} + (4)^{2}}\frac{dD}{dt} &= 2(2)(2) + 2(4)(8) \\ 2\sqrt{20} \frac{dD}{dt} &= 72 \\ \frac{dD}{dt} &= \frac{36}{\sqrt{20}} = \frac{18}{\sqrt{5}} = \frac{18}5 \sqrt{5} \end{aligned}\]

completing the question. All answers in the last line are equivalently correct.
sols_raw:
As discussed in the hint,

:<math> \displaystyle D(t)^{2} = x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}</math>

Differentiating yields

:<math> \displaystyle 2D(t)\frac{dD}{dt} = 2x\frac{dx}{dt} + 2y\frac{dy}{dt}</math>

From the previous part, we have that

:<math> \displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 2</math>

and we are given that

:<math> \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 8</math>

and so plugging in the point <math> \displaystyle (x(t),y(t)) = (2,4)</math>, and <math> \displaystyle D(t) = \sqrt{x(t)^2+y(t)^2} </math> (''D'' must be positive) we have

:<math> 
\begin{align}
 2\sqrt{x(t)^{2} + y(t)^{2}}\frac{dD}{dt} &=   2D(t)\frac{dD}{dt} = 2x(t)\frac{dx}{dt} + 2y(t)\frac{dy}{dt} \\
 2\sqrt{(2)^{2} + (4)^{2}}\frac{dD}{dt} &=  2(2)(2) + 2(4)(8) \\
 2\sqrt{20} \frac{dD}{dt} &=  72 \\
\frac{dD}{dt} &=  \frac{36}{\sqrt{20}} = \frac{18}{\sqrt{5}} = \frac{18}5 \sqrt{5} 
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question. All answers in the last line are equivalently correct.
statement_html:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve \(y = x^{2}\). As it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

ii) What is the rate of change of the particle’s distance \(D(t)\) to the origin at this instant?
statement_latex:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve $y = x^{2}$. As
it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a
rate of 8 units/sec.

ii) What is the rate of change of the particle's distance $D(t)$ to the
origin at this instant?

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH102/December_2011/MATH102_2011_7ii.png}
statement_raw:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve <math>y = x^{2}</math>. As it passes through
the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

ii) What is the rate of change of the particle's distance <math>D(t)</math> to the origin at this instant?
